author: cheeky_gorilla
content:
This is a great initiative <@648121539887366144> !

I have thoughts on this: "[if] I am already using a minority client" [..] "Your ETH is safe from possible supermajority bugs"

If a buggy client has > 2/3 of the staked supply, it would finalize its own chain, as you mentioned. If that happens, the options arent great;

"If the affected validators try to rejoin the correct chain after applying a fix they would be slashed with the maximum correlation penalty.

The only other option is for the remaining non-affected clients to accept the bug, join the new chain and agree that the bug becomes the expected behavior of Ethereum's consensus layer from then on. Those minority clients would then be subject to inactivity penalties on the new chain even though they acted properly. 

The former option is extremely expensive for the affected validators and logistically awkward to correct. The latter option would deeply undermine trust in Ethereum and cause us to accept a permanently tarnished chain."

Quoted text from here: https://mirror.xyz/jmcook.eth/S7ONEka_0RgtKTZ3-dakPmAHQNPvuj15nh0YGKPFriA

Given the above, I agree with your final paragraph ("It is in the best interest of all ETH holders and network users to get the network diversified"). But I wouldnt say that ETH is "safe" from supermajority bugs, as there's still a chance that the buggy chain becomes the canonical chain, purely due to the amount of staked ETH that supported it, which means the "correct validators" would still be penalized.

author: ajsutton
content: The amount of staked ETH does not define the canonical chain.  You can easily have the majority of staked ETH using client A which has a bug but the majority of key users (and thus the majority of real "value" of the chain) uses client B (or multiple clients etc).
